A catch-up is usually a quick meeting to discuss the latest news or progress on a project. "Catch up" can also be used as a verb with the same meaning. The verb can also mean "to do something you did not have time to do earlier". After the verb "to catch up" we use the prepositions "on" or "with". Note that we write the noun with a hyphen (-) and the verb as two separate words!
is an intern in Martha's team.
Your desk is right next to the meeting room.
The Marketing department...

"To be in charge of something" means the same as "to be responsible for something". The verb "to lead" also has a similar meaning. Have a look at the examples below.
to find another time for a meeting.

The word "schedule" can be used as both a noun and a verb. As a noun "schedule" means the same as diary, while as a verb it means "to organise, to set a time" to do something. You will also hear it pronounced in different ways. In British English it is pronounced with a "sh" sound (like "shed-ule"). In American English it is pronounced with a "sk" sound (like "sked-ule").
a short meeting to discuss the latest news

Amazing.
Of course, don't worry. I have a [k]catch-up[/k] with Sophie in the morning, but I'm free in the afternoon. Shall we say 2 p.m.?

A lot of everyday language in the workplace is connected to time: everything needs to happen quickly and efficiently so that time isn't wasted. That's why in English we "grab a coffee" instead of "have a coffee", we ask our colleagues if they "have a minute" instead of "some time" and we ask a "quick" question.

Home Resources
In this lesson we'll learn some everyday language which you'll hear in the workplace.

In this unit we are going to look at some useful vocabulary to talk about the workplace. A company usually has different departments. They are responsible for different areas of work. You can see some examples of different departments below.
department
I am applying for a job in the [k]IT[/k] department.
The IT department...
Oh no! I am so busy today, can we [k]reschedule[/k] it for tomorrow?
on
he will not be able to see you.
John has a full schedule this week, he will not be able to see you.
Complete the sentence by typing a synonym of "to have a good relationship" you learned in this unit.
Ross and I are [k]leading[/k] this project.
The word "meeting" comes from the verb "to meet". An important room in most workplaces is the "meeting room", where groups of people can sit and have private conversations.
a group of people who work on a specific project

A department can consist of different teams. A team is a group of people working on specific projects. In smaller organisations, department and team can be used as synonyms.
Martha is only free in the morning.
The [k]marketing[/k] department is the biggest team in the [k]company[/k].
Ross and I are responsible for this project.
